lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
1. Open IntelliJ (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into IntelliJ as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 21** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

1. After that, locate the `src/main/java/Duke.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run Duke.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:

**Warning:** Keep the `src\main\java` folder as the root folder for Java files (i.e., don't rename those folders or move Java files to another folder outside of this folder path), as this is the default location some tools (e.g., Gradle) expect to find Java files.

- **GUI (JavaFX):** `./gradlew run` (or run `spot.Launcher` from your IDE). This opens the Spot chatbot window. Place **DaUser.png** and **DaSpot.png** in `src/main/resources/images/` for user and Spot avatars (optional; a placeholder is used if missing).
- **Text UI (CLI):** Run `spot.Spot` as the main class (e.g. right-click `Spot.java` → Run). Uses the same commands and data file (`data/spot.txt`).
The project comes with a set of test scripts for different operating systems:
These scripts will compile the source files, run the tests, and compare the output against the expected output.
This project is configured to build a self-contained executable JAR (a “fat jar”) that can be distributed and run without any additional classpath setup.
The executable JAR will be created at `build/libs/spot.jar`.
2. Open a command window in that folder.
Keep going – even the best programmers started out writing 'Hello World'!
The only way to learn a new programming language is by writing programs in it.
Code is like humor. When you have to explain it, it's bad.
First, solve the problem. Then, write the code.
Any fool can write code that a computer can understand. Good programmers write code that humans can understand.
The best error message is the one that never shows up.
Talk is cheap. Show me the code.
Make it work, make it right, make it fast – in that order.
You don't have to be great to start, but you have to start to be great.
Debugging is twice as hard as writing the code in the first place.
Every expert was once a beginner. Every master was once a disaster.
The best time to refactor was yesterday. The second best time is now.
Your code is your craft. Keep sharpening the saw.
- **Keep it short:** aim for **≤ 50 chars** (hard limit **72 chars**).
- **Use imperative mood** (as if completing the sentence “This commit will …”):
- Add a body when the change is not obvious from the subject alone.
- Put a **blank line** between subject and body.
- Use **bullet points** when it improves clarity.
- WHY: why it was needed / why this approach was chosen
- HOW: leave implementation details to the diff
- **If it gets long, split the work**
- A very long explanation is often a sign the commit should be broken into smaller commits.
- Don’t repeat what is already clearly stated in code comments added in the same commit.
- **What is being done** (imperative mood; “Let’s …” is acceptable)
- Avoid words like “currently” / “originally” when describing the current situation (it’s implied).
- If the branch relates to an issue, use:
* A launcher class to work around classpath issues when running JavaFX applications.
* Main window for the Spot chatbot GUI (JavaFX).

hintLabel = new Label("Type a command or say help");
* Handles user input: adds user and Spot dialog boxes and clears the input.
if (spotText.contains("Bye. Hope to see you again soon!")) {
* Main application class for Spot, a command-line task manager.
* Coordinates storage, task list, and UI to process user commands.
* No-argument constructor for use by JavaFX GUI (uses default data file path).
* Creates a Spot instance with storage at the given path and initializes from disk.
* @param filePath path to the task data file (e.g. "data/spot.txt")
* Entry point. Runs Spot with default data file "data/spot.txt".
* Runs the main loop: shows welcome, processes commands until bye, then shows farewell.
* Reads and dispatches user commands until "bye" or end-of-input.
* Processes a single command and writes the response to the current UI.
* @return true if the command was "bye" (caller should exit), false otherwise
assert trimmedInput != null && !trimmedInput.isEmpty() : "runOneCommand expects non-empty trimmed input";
"I don't know what you mean :( Type \"help\" to view a list of functions.");

* @param input the user's command (e.g. "list", "todo buy milk")
* @return the response text to display, or empty string if input is blank
Ui responseUi = new Ui(new Scanner(""), sb);
* Handles the "cheer" command: shows a random motivational quote from data/cheer.txt.
quote = "Keep going – even the best programmers started out writing 'Hello World'!";
assert !quotes.isEmpty() : "random index only used when quotes is non-empty";
* Handles the "find <keyword>" command: shows tasks whose description contains the keyword.
* @param parsedCommand parsed FIND command with keyword argument
* Handles the "on <date>" command: shows deadlines falling on the given date.
* @param parsedCommand parsed ON command with date argument
"I couldn't understand that date. Use yyyy-mm-dd or d/M/yyyy "
* Parses the command argument as a 1-based task index and validates it against the task list.
* Shows an error message and returns empty if the argument is not a number or out of range.
* @return the 0-based task index, or empty if invalid
ui.showFramedMessage("You have to give me the task number!");
* Handles mark or unmark: sets the task at the given 1-based index and persists.
* @param parsedCommand parsed MARK or UNMARK command with task number
assert taskIndex >= 0 && taskIndex < tasks.size() : "task index must be valid after range check";
* Handles delete: removes the task at the given 1-based index and persists.
* @param parsedCommand parsed DELETE command with task number
assert taskIndex >= 0 && taskIndex < tasks.size() : "task index must be valid after range check";
* Handles todo/deadline/event/add: creates a task from the parsed command, adds it, and persists.
* @param parsedCommand parsed TODO, DEADLINE, EVENT, or ADD command
assert newTask != null : "newTask must be non-null when adding after createTask success";
* Supported command types for Spot (list, find, mark, unmark, delete, todo, deadline, event, on, bye, help, cheer).
* Immutable result of parsing a user command: the command type and optional argument string.
* Creates a parsed command with the given type and argument.
* @param argument the argument (e.g. task number, description, date); may be null
assert type != null : "command type must not be null";
* Returns the argument string, or null if none.
* Parses user input into commands and creates Task instances from command arguments.
* Parses a trimmed user input line into a {@link ParsedCommand}.
* @return the parsed command (type UNKNOWN if unrecognized)
assert trimmedInput != null : "trimmed input must not be null";
* Returns a user-facing error message when add/todo/deadline/event parsing fails.
* @param type the command type that failed
* @return short message explaining the expected format
case DEADLINE -> "Deadline must have a description and /by <date>. "
case EVENT -> "Event must have a description, /from <start>, and /to <end>. "
default -> "I need more details. Use: deadline <description> /by <date>, "
* Creates a Task from a parsed add/todo/deadline/event command.
* @param parsedCommand the parsed command (TODO, DEADLINE, EVENT, or ADD)
* @return the created task, or null if the argument format is invalid
assert parsedCommand != null : "parsed command must not be null";
case TODO, ADD -> argument.isEmpty() ? null : new Todo(argument);
yield by == null ? null : new Deadline(description, by);
: "event /from and /to indices must be within argument bounds";
* Parses a date string (yyyy-mm-dd or d/M/yyyy) into a date at start of day.
* @param input the date string; may be null or blank
* @return the parsed date, or null if unparseable

* @param dateTimeString the input string; null or blank returns null
* @return the parsed date-time (midnight if date-only), or null if unparseable

Place DaUser.png and DaSpot.png in this folder for the chatbot GUI avatars.
If the images are missing, the app will show a placeholder until you add them.
* Positive case: "find" command with a keyword is parsed as FIND with the keyword as argument.
* Negative case: "find" with no keyword yields FIND with empty argument; unknown tokens
Task task = Parser.createTask(new ParsedCommand(CommandType.EVENT, "team meeting /from Mon 2pm /to 3pm"));
Deadline d = new Deadline("submit report", by);

* Positive case: findTasks returns only tasks whose display string contains the keyword,
* and matching is case-insensitive so "REPORT" finds "submit report".
TaskList list = new TaskList(List.of(t1, t2, t3, e));
* Negative case: findTasks with null, empty, or non-matching keyword returns an empty list
TaskList list = new TaskList(List.of(new Todo("only task")));
This folder uses input/output redirection to semi-automate testing of the Spot text UI.
As per [Automating the testing of text UIs](https://se-education.org/guides/tutorials/textUiTesting.html).
- **Windows**: From this folder in Command Prompt, run `runtest.bat`
## Updating tests when the program changes
1. Run the test; it will fail if behavior changed.
2. Compare `ACTUAL.TXT` with `EXPECTED.TXT` (e.g. diff tool) and confirm the new behavior is correct.
3. Copy `ACTUAL.TXT` to `EXPECTED.TXT` to accept the new expected output.
4. Re-run the test to confirm it passes.
- **list**: Empty list and list with tasks
- **help**: Help command shows list of functions
- **Error cases**: Unknown command (prompts to type `help`), `mark` without number, empty `todo`, invalid `deadline` (missing `/by`)
When new features are added, extend `input.txt` with more commands and refresh `EXPECTED.TXT` from the new `ACTUAL.TXT` so the tests stay up to date.
This folder uses input/output redirection to semi-automate testing of the Spot text UI.
As per [Automating the testing of text UIs](https://se-education.org/guides/tutorials/textUiTesting.html).
- **Windows**: From this folder in Command Prompt, run `runtest.bat`
## Updating tests when the program changes
1. Run the test; it will fail if behavior changed.
2. Compare `ACTUAL.TXT` with `EXPECTED.TXT` (e.g. diff tool) and confirm the new behavior is correct.
3. Copy `ACTUAL.TXT` to `EXPECTED.TXT` to accept the new expected output.
4. Re-run the test to confirm it passes.
- list: Empty list and list with tasks
- help: Help command shows list of functions
- todo, deadline, event: Adding tasks and confirmation messages
- mark / unmark: Marking tasks done and undone
- delete: Removing a task from the list (and error cases: no number, invalid index)
- Error cases: Unknown command (prompts to type `help`), mark/delete without number, empty todo, invalid deadline (missing /by), delete with non-existent task number
When you add new features, extend `input.txt` with more commands and refresh `EXPECTED.TXT` from the new `ACTUAL.TXT` so the tests stay up to date.
